text.p: Suppose [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline] is a subspace of [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^5[/mathjaxinline], and suppose that [mathjaxinline]e_1, e_3 \in W[/mathjaxinline], but [mathjaxinline]e_2, e_4, e_5 \notin W[/mathjaxinline].
What is the strongest statement we can make about the dimension of [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline]?

font.p: [mathjaxinline]\{ e_1; e_3\}[/mathjaxinline] is a linearly independent set inside [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline], so the dimension of [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline] is at least 2. However, it can be bigger than that; for instance, if [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline] is the span of [mathjaxinline]\{ e_1; e_3; e_2-e_4; e_4-e_5\}[/mathjaxinline] it would have dimension 4 (one can check that those four vectors are linearly independent) and satisfy the requirements.

[mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline] cannot have dimension 5, however, since the only subspace of [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^5[/mathjaxinline] that has dimension 5 is [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^5[/mathjaxinline] itself. Thus the maximum is 4.
